Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech by creating two classes of citizens with different rights to spread information.
The internet is a democratic tool that should not be restricted by excessive fines and broad regulations.
Judging the veracity of information is difficult due to the evolving nature of scientific knowledge.
The bill could have unintended consequences for smaller community websites, imposing unjust fines.
The global nature of the internet makes enforcement of the bill problematic, potentially affecting international platforms.
The bill could infringe on rights guaranteed by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, particularly freedom of thought and expression.
Notable Quotes: The excessive fines imposed on digital services will lead to a chilling effect on free speech, surpassing even the most restrictive digital platforms seen today.
Accurately judging the veracity of information in the digital age is an impossible task.
The bill's potential labeling of fundamental faith worldviews as misinformation displays a concerning level of intolerance.
